message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the necrosis suggests that the embolus passed through the splenic artery, which supplies blood to the proximal portion of the greater curvature of the stomach. The other options do not supply blood to this particular region of the stomach.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the necrosis suggests that the embolus passed through the splenic artery, which supplies blood to the greater curvature of the stomach. The inferior mesenteric artery and left gastric artery do not supply blood to this area, and the right gastroepiploic artery supplies blood to the distal portion of the greater curvature.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an embolic occlusion of an artery, and the location of necrosis in the greater curvature of the stomach suggests the blood supply to this area was cut off. The splenic artery supplies the greater curvature of the stomach, so the embolus most likely passed through this vessel.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the necrosis, which is the proximal portion of the greater curvature of the stomach, suggests that the embolus came through the splenic artery. The other options do not supply blood to the greater curvature of the stomach.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The greater curvature of the stomach is supplied by the left gastroepiploic artery, which branches off from the splenic artery. Therefore, an embolus passing through the splenic artery would most likely cause necrosis in this area. None of the other options supply this area of the stomach with blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the location of the necrosis on the greater curvature of the stomach suggests that the embolic occlusion likely passed through the splenic artery. The other arteries listed do not supply blood to the area of the stomach where the necrosis occurred.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the necrosis suggests involvement of the left gastric artery. The splenic artery supplies the left gastric artery, making it the most likely vessel for embolic occlusion causing necrosis in this location. The other options do not supply this region of the stomach.

We refer to PubMed articles on medicine for help. The location of the necrosis indicates that the embolus occluded an artery that supplies blood to the proximal portion of the greater curvature of the stomach. Among the options, only the splenic artery supplies this area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the necrosis suggests that the artery involved is the left gastroepiploic artery, which branches off the splenic artery. Options A, B, and D are not located in the area of the necrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the necrosis, which is the proximal portion of the greater curvature of the stomach, suggests that the occlusion occurred in the splenic artery. The other options have different supply areas.
